build/ezcgo-apis/admin.title: Admin API
build/ezcgo-apis/admin.description: This API can be used for measuring node health and debugging. Note that the Admin API is disabled by default for security reasons. To run a node with the Admin API enabled, use config flag --api-admin-enabled=true.

build/ezcgo-apis/auth.title: Auth API
build/ezcgo-apis/auth.description: When you run a node, you can require that API calls have an authorization token attached. This API manages the creation and revocation of authorization tokens.

build/ezcgo-apis/c-chain.title: Contract Chain (C-Chain) API
build/ezcgo-apis/c-chain.description: More information ezc.lable regarding EZChain Go APIs and learning how to interact with the C-Chain.

build/ezcgo-apis/deprecated-api-calls.title: Deprecated API Calls
build/ezcgo-apis/deprecated-api-calls.description: This page lists API methods, arguments and responses that are deprecated and will be removed or modified in a future release.

build/ezcgo-apis/health.title: Health API
build/ezcgo-apis/health.description: This API can be used for measuring node health. Use EZChain docs as a reference when testing node health. Helpful examples provided.

build/ezcgo-apis/index-api.title: Index API
build/ezcgo-apis/index-api.description: EZChainGo can be configured to run with an indexer. That is, it saves (indexes) every container (a block, vertex or transaction) it accepts on the X-Chain, P-Chain and C-Chain. To run EZChainGo with indexing enabled, set command line flag --index-enabled to true. EZChainGo will only index containers that are accepted when running with --index-enabled set to true. To ensure your node has a complete index, run a node with a fresh database and --index-enabled set to true. The node will accept every block, vertex and transaction in the network history during bootstrapping, ensuring your index is complete. It is OK to turn off your node if it is running with indexing enabled. If it restarts with indexing still enabled, it will accept all containers that were accepted while it was offline. The indexer should never fail to index an accepted block, vertex or transaction.

build/ezcgo-apis/info.title: Info API
build/ezcgo-apis/info.description: This API can be used to access basic information about the node.

build/ezcgo-apis/ipc.title: IPC API
build/ezcgo-apis/ipc.description: The IPC API allows users to create UNIX domain sockets for blockchains to publish to. Find out more information here.

build/ezcgo-apis/issuing-api-calls.title: Issuing API Calls
build/ezcgo-apis/issuing-api-calls.description: This guide explains how to make calls to APIs exposed by EZChain nodes.

build/ezcgo-apis/keystore.title: Keystore API
build/ezcgo-apis/keystore.description: Every node has a built-in keystore. Clients create users on the keystore, which act as identities to be used when interacting with blockchains. A keystore exists at the node level, so if you create a user on a node it exists only on that node. However, users may be imported and exported using this API.

build/ezcgo-apis/metrics.title: Metrics API
build/ezcgo-apis/metrics.description: The API allows clients to get statistics about a node’s health and performance.

build/ezcgo-apis/p-chain.title: Platform Chain (P-Chain) API
build/ezcgo-apis/p-chain.description: This API allows clients to interact with the P-Chain, which maintains EZChain’s validator set and handles blockchain creation.

build/ezcgo-apis/README.title: Overview
build/ezcgo-apis/README.description: Clients interact with EZChain through APIs calls to nodes. Numeric parameters in API calls may be given as strings (e.g., "5" or 5 are both ok for an integer argument). Numeric return values are always given as strings (e.g., "5" rather than 5). In examples, API calls are made to a node listening for HTTP traffic on 127.0.0.1:9650.

build/ezcgo-apis/x-chain.title: Exchange Chain (X-Chain) API
build/ezcgo-apis/x-chain.description: The X-Chain is an instance of the EZChain Virtual Machine (AVM)

build/references/avm-transaction-seriali.title: AVM Transaction Format
build/references/avm-transaction-seriali.description: This file is meant to be the single source of truth for how we serialize transactions in the EZChain Virtual Machine (AVM). This document uses the primitive serialization format for packing and secp256k1 for cryptographic user identification.

build/references/chain-config-flags.title: Chain Configs
build/references/chain-config-flags.description: Reference for all ezc.lable chain config options and flags.

build/references/coreth-arc20s.title: EZChain Native Tokens and ARC-20s
build/references/coreth-arc20s.description: What is an EZChain Native Token?

build/references/coreth-atomic-transacti.title: Coreth Atomic Transaction Format
build/references/coreth-atomic-transacti.description: This page is meant to be the single source of truth for how we serialize atomic transactions in Coreth. This document uses the primitive serialization format for packing and secp256k1 for cryptographic user identification.

build/references/cryptographic-primitive.title: Cryptographic Primitives
build/references/cryptographic-primitive.description: EZChain uses a variety of cryptographic primitives for its different functions. This file summarizes the type and kind of cryptography used at the network and blockchain layers.

build/references/ezcgo-config-flags.title: EZChainGo Config and Flags
build/references/ezcgo-config-flags.description: This documents list all ezc.lable configuration and flags for EZChainGo.

build/references/network-protocol.title: Network Protocol
build/references/network-protocol.description: EZChain network defines the core communication format between EZChain nodes. It uses the primitive serialization format for payload packing.

build/references/platform-transaction-se.title: Platform Transaction Format
build/references/platform-transaction-se.description: This file is meant to be the single source of truth for how we serialize transactions in EZChain’s Platform Virtual Machine, aka the Platform Chain or P-Chain. This document uses the primitive serialization format for packing and secp256k1 for cryptographic user identification.

build/references/serialization-primitive.title: Serialization Primitives
build/references/serialization-primitive.description: EZChain uses a simple, uniform, and elegant representation for all internal data. This document describes how primitive types are encoded on the EZChain platform. Transactions are encoded in terms of these basic primitive types.

build/tools/abigen.title: Abigen
build/tools/abigen.description: Compile a solidity contract into golang to deploy and call contracts programmatically.

build/tools/dashboards/README.title: Grafana Dashboards
build/tools/dashboards/README.description: These are pre-configured Grafana dashboards that work with the setup as shown in Setting up node monitoring. The script in the linked tutorial will automatically install them.

build/tools/deprecating-ortelius.title: Replacing Ortelius with the Index APIs
build/tools/deprecating-ortelius.description: This guide explains how to replace usage of the Ortelius API with other APIs, including EZChainGo's Index API. Ortelius is deprecated. You should use other EZChainGo APIs to get the information that you used to get from Ortelius.

build/tools/ezc-sim.title: EZChain Local Simulator
build/tools/ezc-sim.description: ezc-sim makes it easy for anyone to spin up a local instance of an EZChain network to interact with the EZChain standard APIs or to test a custom VM.

build/tools/ezchain-wallet-sdk/README.title: Wallet SDK Overview
build/tools/ezchain-wallet-sdk/README.description: The EZChain Wallet SDK is a TypeScript library for creating and managing non-custodial wallets on the EZChain platform.

build/tools/ezchain-wallet-sdk/wallet-cl.title: Wallet Classes
build/tools/ezchain-wallet-sdk/wallet-cl.description: The core of the SDK are the wallet classes that let users easily create and manage different types of wallets. Find out more info here.

build/tools/ezchainjs/create-an-asset-on.title: Create an Asset on the X-Chain
build/tools/ezchainjs/create-an-asset-on.description: This example creates an asset on the X-Chain and publishes it to the EZChain platform. The first step in this process is to create an instance of EZChainJS connected to our EZChain platform endpoint of choice. In this example we're using the local network 12345 via EZCsh. The code examples are written in typescript. The script is in full, in both typescript and javascript, after the individual steps. The whole example can be found here.

build/tools/ezchainjs/manage-x-chain-key.title: Manage X-Chain Keys
build/tools/ezchainjs/manage-x-chain-key.description: EZChainJS comes with its own AVM Keychain. This KeyChain is used in the functions of the API, enabling them to sign using keys it’s registered. The first step in this process is to create an instance of EZChainJS connected to our EZChain platform endpoint of choice.

build/tools/ezchainjs/README.title: Overview
build/tools/ezchainjs/README.description: EZChainJS is a Javascript Library for interfacing with the EZChain platform. It is built using TypeScript and intended to support both browser and Node.js. The EZChainJS library allows one to issue commands to the EZChain node APIs.

build/tools/ezchainjs/send-an-asset-on-t.title: Send an Asset on the X-Chain
build/tools/ezchainjs/send-an-asset-on-t.description: This example sends an asset in the X-Chain to a single recipient. The first step in this process is to create an instance of EZChain connected to our EZChain Platform endpoint of choice.

build/tools/ezcsh.title: EZCsh
build/tools/ezcsh.description: EZCsh is deprecated and is being replaced with the EZChain Network Runner

build/tools/network-runner.title: EZChain Network Runner
build/tools/network-runner.description: The EZChain Network Runner allows a user to define, create and interact with a network of EZChain nodes. It can be used for development and testing.

build/tools/ortelius.title: Ortelius API
build/tools/ortelius.description: This API allows clients to interact with Ortelius, the EZChain indexer.

build/tools/postman-ezchain-collection.title: Postman Collection
build/tools/postman-ezchain-collection.description: Postman is a free tool used by developers to quickly and easily send REST, SOAP, and GraphQL requests and test APIs.

build/tools/public-api.title: Public API
build/tools/public-api.description: There is a public API server that allows developers to access the EZChain platform without having to run a node themselves.

build/tools/README.title: Overview
build/tools/README.description: Public API: Learn about the public API server you can use to interact with the EZChain Network.

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/add-a-.title: Add a Node to the Validator Set

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/hetzne.title: Hetzner Volume Migration
build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/hetzne.description: Hetzner is a cloud provider which can be used to run an EZChain node. It may become necessary to add more disk space to your node as EZChain Network activity grows, however, Hetzner does not provide for local storage expansion (local storage comes with an instance when created).

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/node-b.title: Node Backup and Restore
build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/node-b.description: Once you have your node up and running, it's time to prepare for disaster recovery. Should your machine ever have a catastrophic failure due to either hardware or software issues, or even a case of natural disaster, it's best to be prepared for such a situation by making a backup.

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/run-a-.title: Run a Five Node Network with EZCsh
build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/run-a-.description: EZCsh is deprecated and is being replaced with the EZChain Network Runner

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/run-ez.title: Run an EZChain Node Manually
build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/run-ez.description: The quickest way to learn about EZChain is to run a node and interact with the network and geared toward people interested in how the EZChain Platform works.

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/set-up.title: Run an EZChain Node with Google Cloud Platform
Run an EZChain Node with Microsoft Azure
build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/set-up.description: Running a validator and staking with EZChain provides extremely competitive rewards of between 9% and 11% depending on the length you stake for. Find out more info here.

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/set-up.title: Run an EZChain Node using the Install Script
build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/set-up.description: We have a shell (bash) script that installs EZChainGo on your computer. This script sets up full, running node in a matter of minutes with minimal user input required. Script can also be used for unattended, automated installs.

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/settin.title: Run an EZChain Node with Amazon Web Services (AWS)
build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/settin.description: This tutorial will guide you through setting up an EZChain node on Amazon Web Services (AWS). Cloud services like AWS are a good way to ensure that your node is highly secure, ezc.lable, and accessible.

build/tutorials/nodes-and-staking/stakin.title: Stake EZC, by Validating or Delegating, with the EZChain Wallet

build/tutorials/platform/adjusting-gas-p.title: Adjusting Gas Price During High Network Activity
build/tutorials/platform/adjusting-gas-p.description: This tutorial will help users to adjust their priority fee and max fee cap during high network activity and take advantage of the benefits of dynamic fee transactions.

build/tutorials/platform/integrate-excha.title: Integrate an Exchange with EZChain C-Chain

build/tutorials/platform/launch-your-eth.title: Launch Your Ethereum dApp on EZChain
build/tutorials/platform/launch-your-eth.description: The purpose of this document is to help you with launching your existing Ethereum dapp on EZChain, get the basics of EZChain Platform and how it works.

build/tutorials/platform/sending-transac.title: Sending Transactions with Dynamic Fees using Jezc.cript
build/tutorials/platform/sending-transac.description: This tutorial will help users to send transactions with dynamic fee settings to adjust their priority fee and max fee cap during high network activity using javascript.

build/tutorials/platform/subnets/create-.title: Deploying Subnet with EVM Based Blockchain using EZChainJS
Create a Subnet
build/tutorials/platform/subnets/create-.description: Please checkout subnet-cli for the fast way to create a subnet. You are welcome to read this document to understand how subnet is created.

build/tutorials/platform/subnets/create-.title: Create a Blockchain Running the AVM
Create a Blockchain Running the Subnet EVM

build/tutorials/platform/subnets/deploy-.title: Deploy a Smart Contract on Your Subnet EVM Using Remix and Metamask

build/tutorials/platform/subnets/README.title: Overview
build/tutorials/platform/subnets/README.description: EZChain features 3 built-in blockchains: Exchange Chain (X-Chain), Platform Chain (P-Chain), and Contract Chain (C-Chain). All 3 blockchains are validated and secured by the Primary Network. The Primary Network is a special subnet, and all members of all custom subnets must also be a member of the Primary Network by staking at least 2,000 EZC.

build/tutorials/platform/subnets/setup-d.title: Run a Node on DFK Subnet

build/tutorials/platform/subnets/spaces.title: Spaces: Experimental Implementation
build/tutorials/platform/subnets/spaces.description: Detailed information about this can be found in the README of the SpacesVM project.

build/tutorials/platform/subnets/wagmi.title: WAGMI Subnet Demo
build/tutorials/platform/subnets/wagmi.description: The WAGMI ("We're All Going to Make It") Subnet Demo is a high throughput testbed for EVM (Ethereum Virtual Machine) optimizations. It is parameterized to run at a factor more capacity than Fuji/Mainnet C-Chain and will be used to experiment with release candidates before they make it into an official coreth release.

build/tutorials/platform/transfer-ezc-be.title: Transfer EZC Between the P-Chain and C-Chain
Transfer EZC Between the X-Chain and C-Chain
Transfer EZC Between the X-Chain and P-Chain

build/tutorials/README.title: Overview
build/tutorials/README.description: Check out all of the tutorials that will help you build on EZChain. We would be thrilled if you would like to contribute to our GitHub or suggest a tutorial on Discord!

build/tutorials/smart-contracts/add-ezch.title: Add EZChain to MetaMask Programmatically
build/tutorials/smart-contracts/add-ezch.description: Adding new networks to Metamask is not a trivial task for people that are not technically savvy, and it can be error prone. To help easier onboarding of users to your application it is useful to simplify that process as much as possible. This tutorial will show how to build a simple button in your front-end application that will automate the process of adding the EZChain network to MetaMask.

build/tutorials/smart-contracts/deploy-a.title: Deploy a Smart Contract on EZChain Using Remix and MetaMask

build/tutorials/smart-contracts/using-ha.title: Using Hardhat with the EZChain C-Chain

build/tutorials/smart-contracts/using-tr.title: Using Truffle with the EZChain C-Chain

build/tutorials/smart-contracts/verify-s.title: Verifying Smart Contracts Using Hardhat and Snowtrace
build/tutorials/smart-contracts/verify-s.description: This tutorial assumes that the contract was deployed using Hardhat and that all Hardhat dependencies are properly installed.

build/tutorials/smart-contracts/verify-s.title: Verify Smart Contracts on the C-Chain Explorer
build/tutorials/smart-contracts/verify-s.description: The C-Chain Explorer supports verifying smart contracts, allowing users to review it.

build/tutorials/smart-contracts/verify-s.title: Verifying Smart Contracts with Truffle Verify
build/tutorials/smart-contracts/verify-s.description: This tutorial includes items from the truffle quickstart docs

build/tutorials/smart-digital-assets/cre.title: Create an ERC-20 Token Using Solidity
build/tutorials/smart-digital-assets/cre.description: ERC-20 tokens are the most fundamental and essential concept in Ethereum. This same token standard is adopted in the EZChain ecosystem.

build/tutorials/smart-digital-assets/cre.title: Create an NFT (Part 1)
build/tutorials/smart-digital-assets/cre.description: EZChain also supports non-fungible tokens (NFTs). By definition, each NFT is unique and not perfectly interchangeable for any other NFT.

build/tutorials/smart-digital-assets/wal.title: Create NFTs with the EZChain Wallet

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/distri.title: Distributed File Manager (DFM) using EZChain, IPFS and ReactJS

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/drizzl.title: Create an Auction Bidding on EZChain using ReactJS
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/drizzl.description: Learn how to create an EZChain-based auction bidding with a ReactJS frontend.

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/evotin.title: Create a Voting dApp on EZChain using ReactJS

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/ezc-ch.title: Create a chat dApp using Solidity and ReactJS
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/ezc-ch.description: In this tutorial we will build a decentralized chat application on EZChain's Fuji test-network from scratch. The dApp will allow users to connect with other people and chat with them. We will develop our smart contract using Solidity which will be deployed on EZChain's C-chain. We will have a basic, easy-to-use UI developed using ReactJS. So, let us begin!

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/ezchai.title: How to Create Your Own DAO with EZChain

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/how-to.title: How to mint your own ERC721 on EZChain using Open Zeppelin
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/how-to.description: This tutorial teaches you to deploy your own ERC721 token on EZChain FUJI C-chain testnet.

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/NFT-Ma.title: Getting Started with Create React App
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/NFT-Ma.description: This project was bootstrapped with Create React App.

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/NFT-Ma.title: NFT Marketplace on EZChain
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/NFT-Ma.description: Step by step tutorial to build your own NFT marketplace on EZChain using Hardhat and React.

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/pangol.title: README
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/pangol.description: How to Use The Graph to Query EZChain Data

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/red-de.title: chainlink-external-adaptor
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/red-de.description: Adaptor for communicating smart contract with real world data

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/red-de.title: How to Configure and Use Your Own Chainlink Node And External Adapter In Your EZChain dApp
build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/red-de.description: This tutorial will show you how to setup a Chainlink node with the EZChain Fuji Testnet and create dApp smart contracts utilizing a Chainlink node.

build/tutorials/tutorials-contest/red-de.title: Tutorial: EZChain Signature Verification in a dApp

learn/ezchain-bridge-faq.title: EZChain Bridge (AB) FAQ
learn/ezchain-bridge-faq.description: The EZChain Bridge (AB) can be used to transfer ERC20 tokens from Ethereum to EZChain's C-Chain and vice versa. This document answers common questions about the bridge.

learn/getting-started.title: Getting Started
learn/getting-started.description: The purpose of this tutorial is to give a general overview of EZChain and to serve as a starting point for new users to the EZChain ecosystem. General knowledge of cryptocurrency is assumed, and in particular familiarity with the Ethereum ecosystem. If you don't understand something right away, that's OK. Search for an answer online, and if you don't find it, ask on our Discord.

learn/platform-overview/ezchain-consensu.title: EZChain Blockchain Consensus
learn/platform-overview/ezchain-consensu.description: Consensus is the task of getting a group of computers to come to an agreement on a decision. EZChain is a new consensus protocol that is scalable, robust, and decentralized.

learn/platform-overview/README.title: EZChain Platform Overview
learn/platform-overview/README.description: EZChain features 3 built-in blockchains which includes Exchange Chain (X-Chain), Platform Chain (P-Chain), and Contract Chain (C-Chain).  More info here.

learn/platform-overview/staking.title: Staking
learn/platform-overview/staking.description: Learn how to stake on EZChain by validating or delegating

learn/platform-overview/transaction-fees.title: EZChain Transaction Fee
learn/platform-overview/transaction-fees.description: In order to prevent spam, transactions on EZChain require the payment of a transaction fee. The fee is paid in EZC. Find out more information here.
